My name is Jere Pankka and I graduated in June 2025 with a Master's degree from Aalto University, majoring in Information and Service Management. I am also currently finalizing my second Master's degree at Tampere University, majoring in Software, Web and Cloud. My degree from Aalto combined business with technology, while my studies at Tampere have focused more deeply on the technical side, giving me a strong foundation in both areas. My studies have provided me with expertise in business and data analysis, intermediate knowledge in web development, and basics of mobile development (React Native + Expo). Beyond technical skills, I have gained experience in managing software projects, sustainable software engineering, human-computer interactions, and the Internet of Things. I acted as a Project Manager for a team of seven developers on the COMP.SE.620 course at Tampere University. My role involved typical PM responsibilities such as maintaining the project's big picture and delegating work, while I also actively contributed to the codebase. The project, which featured a Django backend and a Vue + Bootstrap frontend, received full marks. This was a typical software engineering project executed in two-week sprints (5 sprints for implementation and one for QA). The process included sprint retrospectives, weekly group meetings for coding and discussion, and an iterative approach to requirements gathering that began at the project's outset. I have a strong personal interest in sports analytics, which is reflected in my theses. My Aalto thesis (grade 5/5) researched predicting football transfer fees through machine learning, involving data collection, cleaning, feature engineering, and predictive modeling with Python. My second thesis at Tampere University (grade 4/5) focused on automating xG-based football predictions using a Monte Carlo simulation and an MLOps style pipeline for automated weekly predictions. The theses can be provided as a PDF upon further request. My academic background also includes a strong emphasis on CI/CD pipelines and GitHub Actions for automating software and data workflows.

aalto-abstract:
This study aims to find out whether a transfer fee paid for a football player can be explained with performance statistics, which is the player‚Äôs performance before the transfer happened.
Data is gathered from the highest tier of football in five different countries: England, France, Germany, Italy, and Spain. These are the biggest football leagues in the world. Only summer transfers are considered, and the transfers are gathered from years 2018, 2019, 2020, 2021, 2022, 2023 and 2024. From the players transferred during these years, performance statistics from their prior seasons are collected. Several data point exclusions are made, for example loans, free transfers, and goalkeepers are removed. Furthermore, inadequate data points are dropped, for instance if contract length is not found. Dataset is divided into defenders, midfielders, and attackers, each of which have their own regression models. Feature engineering is performed before feature selection. The data is split into training and test sets with 80/20 split.
The main regression model is multiple linear regression. Feature selection is done with backward elimination. In addition, LASSO regression and random forest regression are performed to get benchmarks for the predictive performance and variance explained. LASSO regression performs its own feature selection while feature selection algorithm Boruta is used for random forest. Hyperparameter values of random forest are tuned. The results of the models are verbally analysed and mean squared error and root mean squared error of the predictions and R¬≤ as well as adjusted R¬≤ are used to compare the models and their results.
The results of multiple linear regression show that age, contract length as well as whether they transferred to the Premier League or out of it are statistically significant regardless of the player category. In addition to these not performance related variables, each category has multiple significant predictors that are performance based. For defenders these are percentage of aerial duels won, touches in attacking third, challenges lost, medium pass completion percentage, tackles in the middle third, npxG + xAG, and progressive carrying distance. For midfielders they are goal creating actions, interceptions, challenges lost, passes into final third, pass completion percentage, recoveries and xG. For attackers these are miscontrols, pass completion percentage, shots on target percentage, take-ons leading to a goal, tackled during takeon percentage, xAG and xG.
The results indicate that ‚Äì to some extent ‚Äì it is possible to explain the transfer fee paid with the performance of the player. However, limitations apply, and the results should be interpreted with caution.
tampere-abstract:
Football result modelling has been researched since the 1960s. Different models and features have been used, but earlier literature regarding expected goals (xG) as a feature for the modelling is scarce. This study aims to investigate how xG can be used to simulate past results, which in turn can be used to predict future results. Furthermore, this study has the goal of automating the entire process with CI/CD, resulting in an MLOps style pipeline for the predictions.
Extensive background and literature review are provided on the topic. This is followed by simulation and prediction. Data from the English Premier League from seasons 2020/2021 to 2024/2025 was used for providing historical results. Match-specific shot-level xG was used in combination with Monte Carlo simulation to simulate past results. These simulated results were utilised for future match prediction, which was done with independent Poisson distribution. The ùúÜ values for the Poisson distribution equalled the previous performances of both the home and the away team. The CI/CD pipeline ran automatically every day, and after each matchweek the results were simulated based on xG, and ùúÜ values were updated. The predictions for the next matchweek were made with the new values and the results were provided through an automated Telegram message. The chosen baseline model was the average of bookmaker odds, which has also been utilised in earlier literature. The performance of the models was looked at with the help of four different metrics. These were accuracy, return on investment, mean binomial deviance error and mean squared error.
The model built for the study achieved profitability in the long run. If all predictions for the historical seasons were considered, the accuracy was 50.67 % with a -0.77 % return on investment for a sample size of 1 800 matches. However, the model performed vastly better for later parts of the season, especially when only considering matches where the model had high confidence. If only the second half of the season was considered, the accuracy ranged between 75 % and 87 % for predictions where the model had a high confidence. For these, the return on investment percentages were between 7 % and 12 %. The independent Poisson model outperformed the baseline model in terms of return on investment on most occasions, even though the accuracy was lower.
Limitations included the simplicity of the model and the model being only xG based, omitting possibly relevant features that affect the predictions. Furthermore, xG as a metric itself has limitations. Regardless of the limitations that apply, the results were encouraging.
